text: I'm developing a HuBL theme locally ... can anyone suggest a quick way to output the value of a variable I'm setting, as a sanity test? (It seems like nothing is working all of a sudden..)

Also, I started a HubSpot theme about 5 months ago, and it looks like the <https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate|boilerplate> has changed significantly... are the changes significant and positive? should I scrap my work and start fresh?
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/developer-reference/debugging-and-errors#view-hubl-output>
thanks

If you forked the boilerplate then I would review the changes that occured since you forked and merge in the ones you feel fit your development workflow and will deliver a better experience for content creators.

In the last 5 months, off-hand we introduced Style Fields, Sections, lazy loading, and some accessibility, and performance updates. You can view all of the changes here
<https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate/releases>
Yep, that's the impression I was getting...
This all came from the boilerplate... why would it not be working now? Did I screw up my (theme level) fields.json that bad, or did the way HubSpot handles this stuff change?
I didn't fork it, but maybe I'll fork it and start over ._.
Thank you
Which file is that from?

Remember, the boilerplate is a great starting point and we continually update it based on best practices and functionality in the CMS.

You’re not required to use it. We do however recommend at least looking at it as inspiration for your projects. It also scores well on Google Page Speed Insights so it’s a good base to start from
Yep. I need the example, and I need the help...
It's from `_theme_variables.css` but the samet hing is happening in `css/elements/typography.css` etc
No variables I'm setting anywhere are outputting anything, including some I'm sure worked previously
for some reason in your screenshot it looks like you have a `-` or a `~` where you’re meaning to have a `=` can you verify that?
I'll look to verify that..

`{% set heading_six = theme.typography.heading_six %}`


```{% set table_head_bg_color = color(theme.tables.header_background_color) %}
{% set table_head_font_color = theme.tables.header_text_color.color %}````
I think it's just the font of the design manager
It's "smelling like" I have a syntax error that's f-ing up everything downstream???

Thanks, just wanted to verify that first because it looked strange. The syntax looks correct.
*What does your fields.json look like for your theme?*
It uploads without error fwiw
I tried removing a closing brace and bracket to make sure that wasn't the problem, and sure enough that threw an error
Oh, I'm being an idiot.

Sorry, I'm just setting the variables, not outputting them (in the screenshots I shared).

So the problem isn't fields.json at least :smile:
at least not to the extent it felt like
I'm still having issues but I'll boil it down and ask again if I'm still stuck. Thank you for the help
right but are your theme field values being output where they are supposed to be printed?
At least some of them, which is better than none of them!
Are these variables designed to be available in other files than where they're set?

Then what I would do is look in your code where the values are actually being printed - doublecheck that what is being output is valid CSS. could be something as simple as outputting a number field but leaving off `px` or something needed to be valid CSS
the output looks like myrule { background-color:  }
I'll look and get back to you. Thank you

> Are these variables designed to be available in other files than where they’re set?
Most of the variables are used in the same file but lower in the file

If you search the variable name you should see a set statement, and then a print statement somewhere else in the file.

HubL can be imported  into other files, so depending on how your files are structured you could have one variable in one file that is used in another file.
Gotcha, have to import explicitly. Thank you

What's the designed relationship between modules and themes?

I don't intend to use my modules across multiple themes. If I want to give my card module a brand-colored border or something, but I want to control that color at a theme level, what's the recommended way to do that? Is there an article I can read up on this?

Because I can't refer to HUBL variables from the theme level within modules, isn't that right?

Or am I thinking about this all wrong somehow?
Should I put css that relates to both the module and the theme in /css/components ???
new to HS, learning so much from these convos. Just wanted to say thank you to you both!
